awd_abstract_narration:
Exoplanets are found around many different types and ages of stars.  Many planets circle closer to their host stars than the distance from our Sun to its closest planet, Mercury.  Older stars, however, can have many planets but very few planets located close to the star itself.  This research addresses the question of how planets in systems having two stars that orbit each other, or binary stars, survive.  The Principal Investigator will organize a program for pre-college students with an interest in astronomy who are diagnosed with dyslexia, ADHD, and/or autism spectrum disorder. The goal of the program is to encourage these high schoolers to pursue higher education and to help them overcome obstacles that they could encounter on their way. 

This research will utilize the hierarchical secular three body approximation and will include relevant physical processes, such as general relativity, tides and stellar evolution. The investigators will link their work to astronomical observations by providing specific predictions that are testable when compared to current and future observations. This research expands our knowledge of interactions taking place beyond the limits of our solar system, the regime from which astrodynamics theory originated. Since every star will undergo various post main sequence evolutionary stages this study will provide a detailed analysis of the fate of planetary systems in evolved stellar binaries.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
As stars with masses lower than about eight times the mass of the Sun evolve and exhaust their hydrogen supply, they begin to expand and lose mass until they end their lives as white dwarfs. Interestingly, extrasolar planets have been observed around stars at all stages of evolution, including when the stars burn hydrogen (known as the main-sequence stage) and when they expand and lose mass (known as sub-giant and red-giant branch stages). Planets have been detected even around white dwarfs, which represent the end point of stellar evolution for these stars. Under this grant, the team investigated the evolution of planetary systems around evolving stars. At face value, this task seems complex because most stars have a stellar companion; our Sun had a 50-50 chance of having a companion. Thus, under this grant, we studied how planets in binary systems survive during the different stages of stellar evolution.

 

In particular, we showed that stellar evolution is the primary cause of the deficit of short-period (either on an eccentric or circular orbit) giant planets around sub-giant and giant stars. We also predicted a new class of Hot Jupiters called Temporary Hot Jupiters that form during the post-main-sequence lifetime around Hot stars known as A-type stars. The temperature on these planets is as high as a star, and they will eventually be engulfed as the star begins to expand. Additionally, our body of work predicted the existence of planetary material accreting on white dwarfs and explained how such material reached the vicinity of the white dwarf. The recent discoveries of WD J091405.30+191412.25, a white dwarf likely accreting material from an ice giant planet, and WD 1856+534 b, a Jupiter-sized planet transiting a white dwarf, are the first direct evidence of giant planets orbiting white dwarfs. These two detections seem to support our suggestions. 

 

As part of this project, the PI led a new APS bridge graduate program within the UCLA Physics and Astronomy department. The UCLA graduate division fully funds the program through the Dean of Sciences, and it has the full support of the faculty in the department. PI  is the faculty contact for the program and mentors several of its students.
